abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Tanzania Emergency Power
            Supply Project were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            significant, the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: 1) a key lesson learned is that,
            in certain cases, an emergency operation can be a fitting
            vehicle to carry forward sector dialogue while averting the
            collapse of the power sector due to natural or other crises;
            2) the Bank should consider developing a methodology for
            estimating monitoring indicators to gauge the efficacy of
            emergency receptions; and 3) demand side management measures
            can be an important complement to emergency power.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Emergency Power
            Supply Project is to assist the Government implement its
            emergency measures to avert a prolonged period of severe
            load-shedding, which would cripple economic activities, and
            hinder the delivery of social services. The project will
            provide funds to cover the incremental power supply costs,
            attributable to the 2003 drought. Specifically, the
            International Development Association's (IDA) financial
            contribution, will cover the incremental costs of fuel for
            running the Ubungo Power Plant on Jet A1 fuel through July
            2004, when the Plant will be commissioned to operate on
            indigenous gas, and, the costs due to the purchase of
            electricity produced from the Independent Power Tanzania
            Ltd. (IPTL) Power Plant, operating on heavy fuel oil,
            through February 2005. Given the circumstances, the project
            will assist in avoiding severe load-shedding, and the
            consequent negative impact on the overall economy, and
            delivery of social services. This will benefit not only
            electricity customers, but also those employed in the formal
            and informal services, who would otherwise, lose jobs and
            income due to the economic impact of significant power
            supply interruptions. Moreover, the project will help
            maintain the current momentum of the power sector reform
            program. Both severe load-shedding, and massive tariff
            increases (i.e., a surcharge to fully cover all additional
            thermal generation costs) could jeopardize the sector reform program.

repnme.cdata!:
Tanzania - Emergency Power Supply Project :
            environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The Tanzania Emergency Power Supply
            Project, which finances emergency measures to reduce power
            supply interruptions, discusses potential environmental
            impacts and proposes measures to mitigate them. High
            priority recommendations include: arranging the safe
            disposal of old transformers and scrap material, educating
            workers about the safe handling of hazardous substances,
            supplying firefighting equipment, preventing soil and water
            contamination by building a containment slab and oil-stained
            waste storage area, preparing and testing and emergency
            plan, regularly checking water quality for underground
            contamination, repairing oil separator equipment and
            building a second interceptor for power house effluents,
            improving awareness of proper storage and disposal of oil
            and fuel waste, educating workers about health risks of
            PCBs, removing and replacing contaminated soil, repairing
            air conditioners, equipping first aid kits with essential
            drugs, and replenishing lost or broken lids or slabs to
            avoid risks of injury or death. Medium-level concerns
            include:  conducting regular environmental performance
            reviews, reducing noise impacts by repairing and maintaining
            machines and enforcing protective gear, conducting regular
            acoustic surveys, posting signs of high noise levels,
            providing worker training programs in health and safety
            issues, installing electronic monitoring devices to check
            quality of discharged effluents, in storage areas
            providing/posting additional labeling, warning, and
            instruction--preferably in a local language-for safety and
            proper handling of hazardous substances, and setting up a
            decontamination area.
